description.narrative: The project aims to strengthen the terrestrial system of national protected areas for biodiversity conservation through enhanced representation, management effectiveness, monitoring, enforcement and financing.

activity-description.narrative: Enhanced institutional and communities’ capacity for environmental conservation and use of natural resources for the people in Kachin.
Enhanced institutional and communities’ capacity for environmental conservation and use of natural resources for the people in Sagaing.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: Indicator 1: Increased coverage of Myanmar's terrestrial and aquatic PA network managed by the Forest Department with increased coverage of under-represented ecoregion Indicator 2: Improved habitat condition at local level indicated by percentage change in forest cover measured through remote sensing during the project Indicator 3: Financial Sustainability of PA system (measured through Financial Sustainability Scorecard)

comment.narrative: - 5.6% coverage (3,788,697 ha) of total country land area (NWCD 2013 data) - Baseline data of annual rate of change in forest cover by PA (% change per year) - Financial Sustainability Scorecard (October 2013) 15%

Component 1 Enhanced systemic, institutional and financial frameworks for PA expansion and management - PAs can access diverse sources of funding for management - National land use planning policy incorporates valuation of ES - PAs buffer zones are given specific and consistent legal recognition - Governance of coastal PAs is clarified in national policy and law - legislation passed to enable local use of land within PAs with appropriate safeguards -Capacity Building Scorecard 50% - NWCD/FD wildlife management basic training developed and delivered - 50 staff - MFS wildlife and PA management training curriculum developed 100 staff - UFES syllabus of Wildlife and PA management for 4th year students improved 50 students -50% increase in budget allocated to the protected areas in real terms compared to baseline as indicated by the financial sustainability scorecard. - potential PA list - Preliminary result of national ecosystem
Component 2 Strengthened Management and Threat Reduction in the Target Protected Areas (PAs) and buffer zones - Business plan of a model PA developed -Reduction of threats by monthly patrolling in four demonstration sites -Community participation systems piloted at demonstration PAs and incorporate into management plans -Encounter rate of 2 Hoolock Gibbon groups/km2 and 2.5 ungulate sign observations/100km patrolled for all four demonstration site

Component 1: - The Myanmar Biodiversity Fund was legally registered in July 2019 as the independent sustainable financing mechanism for supporting protected area management. - Mid-term review recommended dropping planned work on national land use planning and coastal governance, formally excluding Hukaung Valley Wildlife Sanctuary from further monitoring against results framework and consider undertaking a socio-economic mapping of terrestrial ecosystems for the PA system planning. However, on request of Rawan Ethnic Leader, the training on “Participatory Land Use Planning for Rawang Community” to promote co-management in the protected areas, to strengthen ICCAs process beyond PAs was provided. - Preparations for the National Red List on ecosystem (Ecosystems, Reptile, Mammal and Bird) is under way, but the red-list of Bird species is finalized. - Based on the legal advice received from the Union Attorney General Office the project supported the Government the Conservation of Biodiversity and Protected Areas (CBPA) Law with its Rules development process and facilitated both government and CSO led consultations. The Rules identify communities’ rights to access and manage natural resources within PA buffer zones, and project continues its support on development of three SOPs/Guidelines on Free, Prior, Informed, Consent (FPIC), Buffer Zones Management Guidelines, and Stakeholder Engagement. These SOPs/Guidelines are in drafts and submitted to Forest Department for review and feedbacks. - Draft CBPA rules that provide a critical entry point for the establishment and co-management of ICCA is finalized and submitted to State Counselor’s Office for approval. - A South-South learning exchange on ICCAs organized from 2 to 8 June 2019 to the Philippines; The key objective of the South-South exchange was to learn about the experiences in the co-management of Protected Areas and ICCAs in relation to the Philippines’ Protected Area system and how these systems could be customized and beneficially applied in the context of Myanmar. - The capacity development strategy and roadmap for Protected Area Management was developed and presented at 4th Project Board Meeting for its approval from Forest Department. - Myanmar Biodiversity Conservation Protected Area Training books for Myanmar Forest School were published in early 2019. - The Capacity Development and Curriculum Development Action Plan for University of Forestry and Environmental Sciences (UoFES) is still being developed. In June 2019, the internal meeting was conducted with the collaboration of UoFES and WCS to discuss the way forward according to the capacity building action plan. A short field training conducted for 3rd-year students from UoFES from 29 to 30 November 2019. The trainings for NWCD PA staff and FD staff were also organized during 2 to 13 December 2019 - Handicraft training for livelihood development, Farmer Led training for sustainable agriculture and livestock, and Training on Tourism Development were organized in partnership with Government and local partner organizations. - Awareness raising or Scout Programme at Schools in competition of Essays and Drawing for Environmental/Biodiversity Conservation to promote environmental knowledge for young generation and the programme were organized in Htamanthi (Hkamti and Homalin) during 11-16 Oct in collaboration with Education Department. - - - For Potential PA list: Two proposed protected areas Lenya National Park and Lenya National Park-Extension have been removed from the list of proposed protected areas they are still designated as Reserve Forests. 18 protected areas are still under development. 4 new areas have been added to the process for a total of 21 proposed protected areas listed in 2019. - The project team focused on gender advancement during several trainings and workshops that were carried-out as part of the pilot community participation management system. Several protected area management strengthening activities were also carried-out and the METT score for the model protected areas were assessed for the second-half of 2019; Biodiversity and Financial Scorecards are being reviewed and the capacity scorecards is under collection. Component 2 - Htamanthi WS Management Plan is being revised for its second round in following NWCD comments on 12 Nov 2019 - The business plan for Htamanthi Wildlife Sanctuary was developed in August 2018 and is now being integrated with the new HWS management plan following public consultations. Revise final version submitted to FD on 13th December. - Threats have been reduced in HWS through regular extensive SMART patrolling, park boundary demarcation, conducting site training for biological monitoring, Snare Removal Trainings for Community Guardians, and Stakeholder Engagement Training for PA staff. - On-going activities in Htamanthi, Biological Monitoring (Gibbon Survey) with local communities, FD staff and WCS) - Support 7 Community Groups around Htamanthi WS area for their establishment in Community Forestry, prepared the Management Plans for them. The study-tours for CF user group/potential CF user group members (total in 10 groups – 7 CF groups and 3 communities interested to establish CF) were arranged to Wu Yang CF in Wai Maw Township in Kachin State and Loi Nyeint CF in Ywa Ngan Village in Shan State. The latter one has the CF site in combination of eco-tourism development. The study tour started on 23rd Sept 2019. - The proposed CF areas are under the land title of “Vacant, Fallow, Virgin”, in this regard, Sagaing Region FD Staff visited for ground-check and required supports will be provided in consultation and collaboration with other relevant government staff for proposing the land as “Protected Public Forest”. - In addition, community participation is promoted through Community Guardians, Community Guards, Community Forestry and Community Management Protected Areas - Hoolock Gibbon auditory surveys have been conducted for Htamanthi Wildlife Sanctuary (Hoolock Gibbon group density per sq. km was used to verify the encounter rates from SMART. Hoolock Gibbon group density per sq. km in Htamanthi WS 3.01/km2; the encounter rate for the hoolock gibbon was increased to 3.01/km square surpassing the EOP target of 2/km square) - Completed renovation of Biodiversity Education Center in Putao, Kachin in Nov 2019.

Outcome 1 - PAs can access diverse sources of funding for management -national land use planning policy incorporates valuation of ES -PA buffer zones are given specific and consistent legal recognition -governance of coastal PAs is clarified in national policy and law -legislation passed to enable local use of land within PAs with appropriate safeguards -NWCD/FD Wildlife Management Basic Training developed and delivered (50 Staff) - MFS Wildlife and PA management training curriculum developed (100 Staff) -UFES syllabus of Wildlife and PA management for 4th year students improved (50 students)
Outcome 2 -Business Plan of model PA (Htamanthi Wildlife Sanctuary) developed -Patrolling and monitoring in four PAs (FD staff will take responsibility for these actions) -Community participation systems piloted at demonstration PAs and incorporated into Management Plans -Forest Cover Change and Biodiversity Monitoring through Google Earth Engine Analysis

Key results under project (cumulative): 1. The consultation process for the Conservation of Biodiversity and Protected Area Rules development was conducted through a series of workshops in 2018 and 2019. The draft rules were developed taking account of all relevant comments received and agreed from the stakeholders as well as international experts involved in the process. The draft rules focused on co-management for effective PA management and biodiversity conservation with a significant change for PA categories including “Local Community Protected Area”.
2. The main core of the project was implementing NBSAP (2015-2020) and Aichi Biodiversity Targets by 2020 “knowledge, the science base and technologies relating to biodiversity, its values, functioning, status and trends, and the consequences of its loss, are improved, widely shared and transferred, and applied”. Therefore, a Capacity Development Strategy and Action Plan for PA management was developed to be able to support an institutionalized capacity building program for the long term.
3. The institutionalized capacity building programs for PA management were conducted during the project. Basic wildlife management trainings were conducted at Popa Mountain Park in central Myanmar. In addition, curricula for biodiversity conservation and PA management have been developed for Myanmar Forest School and Central Forestry Development and Training Centre. The course module for 4th year students of the University of Forestry and Environmental Science was drafted and it will continue with the external funds after the end of the project.
4. The National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan (NBSAP) was developed to ensure Myanmar will achieve the Aichi Targets. Target 12.3 states that by 2020 a National Red List of selected taxa will be produced. As a follow up for implementation of the strategy, Forest Department, IUCN, WWF and WCS jointly conducted a series of trainings and workshops for developing a National Red List of Threatened Species since July 2017. The first national red list covering 32 mammals, 66 reptiles & amphibians and 19 birds was documented by the end of project and the process for remaining species will be continued with new opportunities of external funded projects as outlined in the project exit strategy.
5. Myanmar NBSAP’s Target 14.1, explicitly states that a “national ecosystem assessment [will] be carried out identifying the status, values, and trends of key ecosystems and the services they provide” before 2020. The project has developed a National Red List of Ecosystems since October 2017 to meet with this national target. A total of 64 different ecosystems have been verified through ground truthing and multi-expert consultations. The results have been documented as a significant output from the project.
6. Strengthening community participation in PA management was implemented through trainings on community guardians and social mobilization of local youth living around project sites. The advanced trainees were recruited as community guards in order to fill gaps to support government staff to strengthen PA management. Protected Area Management Coordination Committees (PAMCCs) were established in state, region, district, and township levels so that multiple stakeholder dialogue was encouraged for effective understanding and implementation of PA management.
7. Another, significant output for the project, the Myanmar Biodiversity Fund (MBF) was officially registered in July 2019 as the very first conservation trust fund in Myanmar. It is an independent conservation fund aiming to fill gaps for protected area management and to increase the role of community-based natural resource management through sustainable financing mechanisms.
